prior_works.title: A Kernel Two-Sample Test
prior_works.authors: Arthur Gretton, Karsten M. Borgwardt, Malte J. Rasch, Bernhard Schölkopf, Alexander J. Smola
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s degree-one kernelized cumulant recovers the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD), making Gretton et al.’s kernel two-sample framework the direct baseline that the new higher-degree cumulants generalize.

prior_works.title: Measuring Statistical Dependence with Hilbert-Schmidt Norms (HSIC)
prior_works.authors: Arthur Gretton, Olivier Bousquet, Alexander J. Smola, Bernhard Schölkopf
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors show that their degree-one cross-cumulant specializes to HSIC, so the HSIC construction is explicitly subsumed as the first-order instance of their cumulant hierarchy.

prior_works.title: Hilbert Space Embeddings and Metrics on Probability Measures
prior_works.authors: Bharath K. Sriperumbudur, Arthur Gretton, Kenji Fukumizu, Bernhard Schölkopf, Gert R. G. Lanckriet
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Results on characteristic kernels justify when RKHS embeddings are injective; the paper leverages this logic to argue identifiability/diagnostic power for their higher-order kernelized cumulants.

prior_works.title: Tensor Methods in Statistics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: McCullagh’s treatment of cumulants as tensors and as the log of the moment generating series provides the algebraic blueprint the authors lift to RKHS via tensor algebras.

prior_works.title: On a Method of Calculation of Semi-Invariants
prior_works.authors: V. P. Leonov, A. N. Shiryaev
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The combinatorial relations between moments and cumulants and the additivity of cumulants for independent sums underpin the theoretical properties the paper extends to the RKHS setting.

prior_works.title: Signature Moments to Characterize Laws of Stochastic Processes
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By casting moments as tensor series (expected signatures) and using their logarithms for characterization, this work supplies the tensor-algebra perspective the paper adapts to define kernelized cumulants.

prior_works.title: Kernels for Sequentially Ordered Data (Signature Kernels)
prior_works.role: Kernelizing tensor series with a kernel trick
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Methods for realizing infinite tensor-feature series via kernel tricks and dynamic programming directly inspire the paper’s claim of computational tractability for higher-degree cumulant features.

synthesis_narrative:
Kernelized Cumulants: Beyond Kernel Mean Embeddings builds by fusing two mature lines of work: RKHS embeddings of probability laws and the algebra of cumulants via tensor series. On the RKHS side, the kernel mean embedding and MMD (Gretton et al. 2012) and HSIC (Gretton et al. 2005) provide the canonical degree-one statistics for two-sample testing and independence; the paper explicitly recovers both as the first layer of its construction. Sriperumbudur et al. (2010) contributes the notion of characteristic kernels, ensuring injective embeddings and thus grounding when such statistics are informative—logic that extends to higher-order cumulant embeddings.
On the statistical side, McCullagh (1987) formalized cumulants as tensors and as logarithms of moment-generating series, while Leonov–Shiryaev (1959) supplied the precise combinatorial moment–cumulant relations and key properties like additivity under independence. The paper’s core innovation is to transplant this cumulant–log–tensor algebra into RKHS: define moment tensors for embedded data, take their tensor-log to obtain kernelized cumulants, and inherit classical cumulant advantages (e.g., variance reduction).
A final enabling ingredient comes from tensor-algebra kernels for sequences (Király & Oberhauser 2019) and related signature-moment ideas (Chevyrev & Oberhauser 2018), which show how infinite tensor feature series can be handled via kernel tricks. This machinery underwrites the paper’s computational claim: higher-degree cumulants can be evaluated with kernel operations at essentially the same complexity as degree-one methods, while offering richer, more robust statistics.
